content: The results of "Test 2 (Collision)" and "Validator 2 (Collision)" seems should be "LOSE", not "WIN" ?

This could be interesting, but the way the subject is currently worded does make it a bit offputting.

Improvement suggestions:
- Replace the first paragraph with an actual introduction to the problem. An elaborate "This is an implementation of castle siege".
- This entails: drop the tedious variable description entirely from the subject section: the're better fit for the inputs section.
- Either move the tower's choosing criteria in the round 1 description, or add a "using algorithm below" placeholder.
- tower priority uses the word "closest". This would need detail (Manhattan? Max? Euclid distance?)
- the clause that 0-HP units are valid targets makes things more complicated than necessary. If I read the rules properly, this can only happen during the first round anyway, so it's probably best to just drop that.
- enemies can be targetted by multiple towers. A note confirming it's legit and reminding HP decreases accordingly would be appreciated.
I like this one. But 20 minute clashes are almost never played. If you knock off a rule or two, we could shift it into 10 minute clashes.

Yeah, when I first thought of it I wanted to put it in the 10 minutes as well, however when I realised the implementation necessary I had no choice but to make it 20 mins. I'll try and make the towers have less priority rules; that is currently the biggest drain I think.

I think the 0 HP clause is so that the order in which towers attack does not affect which targets they choose.
Just stating that the towers all attack simultaneously might be enough.

No because there is a rule in phase 3 that if an enemy collides with a tower, the enemy is destroyed.  I was going to make there some rules for enemy tower avoidance, but this seemed for anyone to have to program, even for a 20 minute clash. Also the player does not win until the following turn (see the phase description for when the player can win or lose).
OK thanks. In my wrong understanding  the Tower is destroyed when an enemy arrive.
Thanks for your comment. I have updated the description so that it is clear that the enemy is destroyed.

Good point. (I had read it assuming HP decrease was in phase 2).

So new suggestion: make HP decrease a part of phase 2. This allows simplification of the confusing 0-HP case.

Each criteria is used to break ties in the previous criteria, so the criteria (enemy closest to the tower) is used to break the tie of a number of enemies equally far North. So in this case the enemies have the same y position and Manhattan and Euclidean would produce the same results in determining the closest enemy to the tower (of the furthest North enemies).

You can instead create more than one CoC:
* A 10 minute one with less rules (for example only one tower),
* The 20 minute ont with all the rules.
